raw_text:
Radcliffe yet to answer GB call
 
 Paula Radcliffe has been granted extra time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships.
 
 The 31-year-old is concerned the event, which starts on 19 March in France, could upset her preparations for the London Marathon on 17 April. "There is no question that Paula would be a huge asset to the GB team," said Zara Hyde Peters of UK Athletics. "But she is working out whether she can accommodate the worlds without too much compromise in her marathon training." Radcliffe must make a decision by Tuesday - the deadline for team nominations. British team member Hayley Yelling said the team would understand if Radcliffe opted out of the event. "It would be fantastic to have Paula in the team," said the European cross-country champion. "But you have to remember that athletics is basically an individual sport and anything achieved for the team is a bonus. "She is not messing us around. We all understand the problem." Radcliffe was world cross-country champion in 2001 and 2002 but missed last year's event because of injury. In her absence, the GB team won bronze in Brussels.
llama3.2:1b: Paula Radcliffe has been granted extra time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships due to concerns about its impact on her marathon training.
llama3.2:3b: Paula Radcliffe has been granted extra time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships on March 19.
She is concerned it may disrupt her London Marathon training schedule, which starts April 17.
The UK Athletics team would welcome her participation but understands if she decides not to compete, saying they prioritize individual achievements over team goals.
gemma2:2b: Paula Radcliffe is considering whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships due to concerns about its impact on her marathon training schedule.
The deadline for team nominations is Tuesday, and she must decide by then if she will participate.
The British team understands her decision and would welcome her inclusion.
Despite missing the last race due to injury, Radcliffe has won the world title twice before and remains a valuable asset to the GB team.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Paula Radcliffe hasn't been asked to compete at the World Cross-Country Championships (WCXCs).
She has worked out whether she can accommodate the London Marathon without compromising her marathon training for 19 March.
British team member Hayley Yelling said it would be fantastic if Radcliffe decides not to participate in the event.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Paula Radcliffe has been granted extra time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships due to concerns about potentially upsetting her marathon training preparations for London Marathon.
qwen2.5:3b: Paula Radcliffe has been granted more time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships due to concerns about disrupting her marathon training for London Marathon on 17 April.
UK Athletics believes she would be a significant asset to the British team, but Radcliffe is assessing if she can fit the event into her schedule without compromising her training.
She has until Tuesday to make a decision.
While Zara Hyde Peters and Hayley Yelling support her participation, they understand the need for her to prioritize her marathon preparation.
Radcliffe missed last year's championships due to injury, and in her absence, GB team won bronze.
opencoder:1.5b: "Paula Radcliffe has been granted extra time to decide whether to compete in the World Cross-Country Championships.
She is concerned about the event that starts on 19 March in France could upset her preparations for the London Marathon on 17 April.
She said the decision would be made by Tuesday, with British team member Hayley Yelling anticipating the team might accept Radcliffe."

The 31-year-old athlete is concerned that the event, which starts on March 19th in France, could potentially disrupt her marathon training.

Team members Hayley Yeolling expressed understanding for Radcliffe's decision, stating that athletics is mainly an individual sport and any achievements obtained by the team are a bonus.
